overview: This subject provides an overview of the framework for prevention and early intervention in public health, including how this framework can be applied in youth mental health. The content includes:

• The prevention and early intervention framework
  • Universal prevention approaches in youth mental health
  • Selective prevention approaches in youth mental health
  • Indicated prevention approaches in youth mental health
  • Mental health promotion
  • Evidence-informed community awareness programs
  • Evidence-informed school-based mental health prevention
ilo: Outline models of mental health promotion
Explain community focused strategies for the universal prevention of mental ill-health in young people
Explain community focused strategies for the indicated prevention of mental ill-health in young people
Discuss the evidence and rationale for early detection and intervention in young people
Explain strategies for the selective prevention of mental ill-health in young people
generic_skills: Capacity to translate knowledge into practice
Ability to find, evaluate and use relevant information
Capacity for logical and independent thought

Inherent requirements (core participatio.content: Further details on how to seek academic adjustments can be found on the Student Equity and Disability Support website:http://services.unimelb.edu.au/student-equity/home

assessment.brief: Online Quizzes of learning content – two multiple choice quizzes with 10 questions each = 20 questions in total (1% per question)
Graded discussion board – posting fortnightly reflections on learning content and responding to fellow students, with a minimum of 7 posts in total

date_times.contact_hours: Online equivalent to 20 contact hours is made up of 10 hours of lectures and live consultation sessions, and 10 hours of asynchronous discussions and structured online tasks.
